title: John ‘Jo’ Lancaster, test pilot who in 1949 was the first British airman to have his life saved in an emergency by an ejector seat – obituary
text:
John “Jo” Lancaster, who has died aged 100, became the first man to use a British ejector seat in an emergency when he was forced to abandon his out-of control experimental jet aircraft in May 1949.

Lancaster was a test pilot for Armstrong Whitworth (AW) Aircraft. The company had proposed making a flying-wing jet airliner, and to test the high-speed characteristics of this new tail-less aircraft, two experimental half-size planes, named AW 52, were built.

On May 30 1949 Lancaster took off from the Armstrong Whitworth airfield at Bitteswell in Leicestershire to test the performance at speed of the first prototype AW 52 (TS 363). It was his third flight in the aircraft, and it was fitted with the...
description: John “Jo” Lancaster, who has died aged 100, became the first man to use a British ejector seat in an emergency when he was forced to abandon his out-of control experimental jet aircraft in May 1949.
